prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 imaging of G207
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: synthesis mosaic imaging of HCO+/H13CO+/CS/cont. in Band 3 toward G207

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution of 0.15 km/s or less for HCO+, CS, and their isotopologues lines are requested to ensure line profiles are fully resolved for turbulence studies. One baseband is reserved for imaging dust continuum emission but employs a moderate spectral resolution for line (contamination) detection purpose.

We request synthesis imaging at an angular resolution of 3" toward the three mosaic fields. The desired spatial scale coverage is to probe thermal Jeans' scales (0.0067pc to 0.14pc, or 3" to 60" at ~ 450 pc) for molecular gas at densities ranging from 10^{4} cm^{-3} to 5 10^{6} cm^{-3} at around 13K, typical of PCC clumps to those in dense cores. With ALMA observations, we focus at substructures spanning from 15" to 3". We have obtained or will obtain single-element mapping of the same sets of transitions (with for example IRAM 30m, NRO 45m, and KVN) for recoving structures larger than 15".

We request ALMA Cycle 3 synthesis mosaic imaging observations at an angular resolution of 3" in Band 3 and Band 4 to probe the molecular gas parameters related to fragmentation and evolution in three fields toward G207, including G207N1, HH58, and G207S4.
In Band 3, we utilize three basebands of the powerful ALMA correlator for accessing HCO+, H13CO+, and CS transitions while reserving one primarily for continuum imaging. The dual polarization mode is used for better noise performance.
We demonstrate the sensitivity requirement based on previous observations of the G207 region. Continuum: Based on JCMT/SCUBA-2 imaging, the target regions are expected to have 30mJy within the SCUBA beam, which translates to around 1mJy per 3" synthesis beam at Band 3 and 4mJy per 3" synthesis beam at Band 4.
Line: The HCO+ (1-0) gives an average brightness temperature of roughly 1K--2K at a 2' scale and up to 3K or more toward the emission peaks in the single-element telescope beam of 20$"$.
In Band 3, the sensitivity requirement is driven by H13CO+, which would be just roughly a factor of 2-3 weaker than HCO+ based on single-element observations toward, for example, IRDCs by Rathborne et al. (2008). We request accordingly a brightness sensitivity of 0.1 K. At a spectral resolution of ~ 0.15 km/s to resolve the line shape for turbulence studies, the proposed observation would allow a SNR of at least 10 toward the dense compact regions and at least 3 toward the outer extended area in the mosaic fields.
The high data rate is strongly desired as high spectral resolutoin is required to resolve the narrow line profiles for turbulence studies.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 4 imaging of G207
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: full synthesis imaging of DCO+/CS/C34S/cont. in Band 4 toward G207

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution of 0.12 km/s for HCO+, CS, and their isotopologues lines are requested to ensure line profiles are fully resolved for turbulence studies. One baseband is reserved for imaging dust continuum emission but employs a moderate spectral resolution for line (contamination) detection purpose.

We request synthesis imaging at an angular resolution of 3" toward the three mosaic fields. The desired spatial scale coverage is to probe thermal Jeans' scales (0.0067pc to 0.14pc, or 3" to 60" at ~ 450 pc) for molecular gas at densities ranging from 10^{4} cm^{-3} to 5 10^{6} cm^{-3} at around 13K, typical of PCC clumps to those in dense cores. With ALMA observations, we focus at substructures spanning from 15" to 3". We have obtained or will obtain single-element mapping of the same sets of transitions (with for example IRAM 30m, NRO 45m, and KVN) for recoving structures larger than 15".

We request ALMA Cycle 3 synthesis mosaic imaging observations at an angular resolution of 3" in Band 3 and Band 4 to probe the molecular gas parameters related to fragmentation and evolution in three fields toward G207, including G207N1, HH58, and G207S4.
In Band 4, we utilize three basebands of the powerful ALMA correlator for accessing DCO+, CS, and C34S transitions while reserving one primarily for continuum imaging. The dual polarization mode is used for better noise performance.
We demonstrate the sensitivity requirement based on previous observations of the G207 region. Continuum: Based on JCMT/SCUBA-2 imaging, the target regions are expected to have 30mJy within the SCUBA beam, which translates to around 1mJy per 3" synthesis beam at Band 3 and 4mJy per 3" synthesis beam at Band 4.
Line: The HCO+ (1-0) gives an average brightness temperature of roughly 1K--2K at a 2' scale and up to 3K or more toward the emission peaks in the single-element telescope beam of 20$"$.
In Band 4, the sensitivity requirement is driven by D13CO+, which will be roughly at 0.5% to 1% level in its abundance as compared to HCO+ based on Chen et al. (2011) and Miettinen et al. (2011), for example. This translates to expected line intensity a factor of 1-3 less than H13CO+ if a Galactic C12/C13 ratio of ~80 is assumed. This range of line ratios is indeed consistent with the line intensity ratios between H13CO+ (3-2) and DCO+ (3-2) observed by Miettinen et al. (2011). We request accordingly a brightness sensitivity of 0.05 K. At a spectral resolution of ~ 0.12 km/s to resolve the line shape for turbulence studies, the proposed observation would allow a SNR of at least 20 toward the dense compact regions and around 5 toward the outer extended area in the mosaic fields.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Planck Early Cold Cores Catalog (ECC) provides an unbiased list of 915 Galactic cold objects with reliable detections and low (dust) temperatures (<14 K). Their very cold and quiescent nature strongly suggests these objects at an earlier phase in the process of forming stars or clusters than IRDCs. With the requested observation, we aim at characterizing the internal physical and chemical structure of G207.3-19.8, a representative Plank cold clump object, with particular emphasis over parameters related to the fragmentation and evolution signatures of the substructures within the region. While the time request is very demanding, only ALMA's powerful capability is able to simultaneously provide the necessary high sensitivity and spectral resolution. We aim at ultimately achieve full synthesis maps, which will enable investigations of the fragmentation process at scales from extended to compact. The proposed observations are expected to readily deliver a wealthy and detailed picture of G207.3-19.8, which will serve as an pivotal reference template for future investigations of Planck cold objects.
